natural problem: What is the probability that the square root of a randomly selected two-digit whole number is less than eight? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: There are 90 choices for a two-digit positive integer. Of these, all of the integers $n<64$ satisfy $\sqrt{n} < 8$.
So, $n$ can be chosen from the set $\{ 10, 11, 12, \ldots , 63\}$ which has 54 members.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "n \<le> 99"
and h2 : "randomly_selected n"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>n. sqrt (real n) < 8) = 3 / 5"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that the square root of a randomly selected two-digit whole number is less than eight? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{5}
 ### Proof
 There are 90 choices for a two-digit positive integer. Of these, all of the integers $n<64$ satisfy $\sqrt{n} < 8$.
 So, $n$ can be chosen from the set $\{ 10, 11, 12, \ldots , 63\}$ which has 54 members.
 So the probability is $\frac{54}{90} = \boxed{\frac{3}{5}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "n \<le> 99"
and h2 : "randomly_selected n"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>n. sqrt (real n) < 8) = 3 / 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the probability that the square root of a randomly selected two-digit integer is less than 8? The final answer is $\frac{3}{5}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes two_digit_numbers sqrt_less_than_eight :: nat
assumes h0 : "two_digit_numbers = {n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99}"
and h1 : "sqrt_less_than_eight = card {n \<in> two_digit_numbers. sqrt n < 8}"
shows  "rat_of_nat sqrt_less_than_eight / rat_of_nat (card two_digit_numbers) = 3 / 5"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that the square root of a randomly selected two-digit whole number is less than eight? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{5}
 ### Proof
 There are 90 choices for a two-digit positive integer. Of these, all of the integers $n<64$ satisfy $\sqrt{n} < 8$.
 So, $n$ can be chosen from the set $\{ 10, 11, 12, \ldots , 63\}$ which has 54 members.
 So the probability is $\frac{54}{90} = \boxed{\frac{3}{5}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes two_digit_numbers sqrt_less_than_eight :: nat
assumes h0 : "two_digit_numbers = {n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99}"
and h1 : "sqrt_less_than_eight = card {n \<in> two_digit_numbers. sqrt n < 8}"
shows  "rat_of_nat sqrt_less_than_eight / rat_of_nat (card two_digit_numbers) = 3 / 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: What is the probability that a randomly chosen two-digit number has a square root less than 8? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final answer is $\frac{3}{5}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> (P n = 1 / 90)"
and h1 : "card {n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> sqrt (real n) < 8} = 54"
shows  "(\<Sum>n \<in> {n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> sqrt (real n) < 8}. P n) = 3 / 5"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that the square root of a randomly selected two-digit whole number is less than eight? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{5}
 ### Proof
 There are 90 choices for a two-digit positive integer. Of these, all of the integers $n<64$ satisfy $\sqrt{n} < 8$.
 So, $n$ can be chosen from the set $\{ 10, 11, 12, \ldots , 63\}$ which has 54 members.
 So the probability is $\frac{54}{90} = \boxed{\frac{3}{5}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> (P n = 1 / 90)"
and h1 : "card {n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> sqrt (real n) < 8} = 54"
shows  "(\<Sum>n \<in> {n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> sqrt (real n) < 8}. P n) = 3 / 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: For all two-digit positive integers $n$, let $P(n) = \frac{1}{90}$. There are 54 such integers $n$ for which $\sqrt{n} < 8$. Find the sum of $P(n)$ for all such integers. The final answer is $\frac{3}{5}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum>n\<in>{x::nat. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 63}. 1) / (\<Sum>n\<in>{x::nat. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 99}. 1)"
shows  "p = 3 / 5"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that the square root of a randomly selected two-digit whole number is less than eight? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{5}
 ### Proof
 There are 90 choices for a two-digit positive integer. Of these, all of the integers $n<64$ satisfy $\sqrt{n} < 8$.
 So, $n$ can be chosen from the set $\{ 10, 11, 12, \ldots , 63\}$ which has 54 members.
 So the probability is $\frac{54}{90} = \boxed{\frac{3}{5}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum>n\<in>{x::nat. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 63}. 1) / (\<Sum>n\<in>{x::nat. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 99}. 1)"
shows  "p = 3 / 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: What is the probability that a randomly chosen number between 10 and 99 inclusive lies between 10 and 63 inclusive? The final answer is $\frac{3}{5}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 10 = 1 / 90"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 10 \<and> n < 100 \<longrightarrow> P n = 1 / 90"
and h2 : "sqrt (Real n) < 8 \<longleftrightarrow> n \<le> 64"
shows  "sum P {n. n \<in> {10..99} \<and> sqrt (Real n) < 8} = 3 / 5"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that the square root of a randomly selected two-digit whole number is less than eight? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{5}
 ### Proof
 There are 90 choices for a two-digit positive integer. Of these, all of the integers $n<64$ satisfy $\sqrt{n} < 8$.
 So, $n$ can be chosen from the set $\{ 10, 11, 12, \ldots , 63\}$ which has 54 members.
 So the probability is $\frac{54}{90} = \boxed{\frac{3}{5}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 10 = 1 / 90"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 10 \<and> n < 100 \<longrightarrow> P n = 1 / 90"
and h2 : "sqrt (Real n) < 8 \<longleftrightarrow> n \<le> 64"
shows  "sum P {n. n \<in> {10..99} \<and> sqrt (Real n) < 8} = 3 / 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider a function $P(n)$ such that $P(10) = \frac{1}{90}$, and for all natural numbers $n$ greater than 10 and less than 100, $P(n) = \frac{1}{90}$. Given that $\sqrt{n} < 8$ if and only if $n \leq 64$, find the sum of $P(n)$ for all $n$ in the range $10 \leq n \leq 99$ and $\sqrt{n} < 8$. The final answer is $\frac{3}{5}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> n \<in> {10..63}. 1) / (\<Sum> n \<in> {10..99}. 1)"
shows  "p = 3 / 5"

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> n \<in> {10..63}. 1) / (\<Sum> n \<in> {10..99}. 1)"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: What is the probability that a randomly chosen number from the set {10, 11, 12, ..., 99} is between 10 and 63 inclusive? The final answer is $\frac{3}{5}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "probability = card {n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> sqrt (real_of_int n) < 8} / card {n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99}"
shows  "probability = 3 / 5"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> p x = 1 / 90"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. (x < 10) \<or> (x > 99) \<longrightarrow> p x = 0"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. p x) {x. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 63} = 3 / 5"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that the square root of a randomly selected two-digit whole number is less than eight? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{5}
 ### Proof
 There are 90 choices for a two-digit positive integer. Of these, all of the integers $n<64$ satisfy $\sqrt{n} < 8$.
 So, $n$ can be chosen from the set $\{ 10, 11, 12, \ldots , 63\}$ which has 54 members.
 So the probability is $\frac{54}{90} = \boxed{\frac{3}{5}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> p x = 1 / 90"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. (x < 10) \<or> (x > 99) \<longrightarrow> p x = 0"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. p x) {x. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 63} = 3 / 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A probability function $p(x)$ is defined such that for any two-digit integer $x$ between $10$ and $99$, inclusive, $p(x) = \frac{1}{90}$. For all other values of $x$, $p(x) = 0$. Find the sum of the probabilities of $x$ between $10$ and $63$, inclusive. The final answer is $\frac{3}{5}$.
